Award.AwardTitle: Building Analytical Competence for Geoscience Students through use of Spectroscopic Tools

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The project, a collaborative effort among Smith College, Holyoke Community College and Mount Holyoke College, is building analytical competence in undergraduate geoscience students through use of Raman and FTIR spectrometers. Benchtop and portable spectrometers are being shared among the three colleges and others in the region, and are being used to develop, implement and assess innovative instructional modules through which students acquire mastery via hands-on, investigative learning. By analyzing unknown minerals and other materials, synthesizing data and predictions, and evaluating experimental results, students are learning not only geological content, but also how to use chemical analyses to solve relevant problems.

The spectroscopic knowledge and analytical competencies that are targeted in the curriculum development are in increasing demand by the nation's geoscience workforce. The project is providing a direct benefit in broadening participation in the geosciences through its engagement with two women's colleges and a community college that serves a diverse population of non-traditional and first-generation college students. Project personnel are also disseminating their approach and curriculum modules beyond the region through a web portal, video postings, and hands-on workshops at national conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Minerals are colored because they selectively adsorb light of certain wavelengths.  Minerals also selectively adsorb infrared radiation of certain wavelenghs that humans cannot see.  Fourier Transform Infrared (FTIR) Spectrometry is a way to see which infrared wavelengths are adsorbed by a mineral. With this grant, we have demonstrated that FTIR spectrometry is a feasible, useful, and appropriate addition to undergraduate Geoscience courses at the introductory and intermediate level. We found that our students could learn to use on their own commercially available benchtop FTIR spectrometers. To make this possible, we developed databases of mineral spectra and procedures, including a website, for student use of those databases. For many common minerals, reflection FTIR spectra that needed no sample preparation could be used to identify and characterize the minerals. Although we also had students collect Raman spectra with benchtop spectrometers, good Raman spectra were more difficult to collect and analyze than FTIR spectra. Assessment of student learning showed that the addition of spectrometry to our classes increased student understanding of minerals and of the ways to study them.  The great majority of students who participated in this project are women, who are underrepresented in the Geosciences. The addition of FTIR spectrometry to the training of Geoscience students will improve their effectiveness in their careers, especially in the mineral resources and environmental fields.
